body: The double invalid stuff looks fishy.
invalidVersions is for versions with invalid devices only. i just thought dropping one of the device lists there  didn't merit a separate fileversion type (now one list is always empty)
I think keep the old message type so old migrations etc are OK, and add a new VersionListV2?

Keeping the old messages is not the problem, that's simple and no maintenance burden. The problem is that old migrations use `updateGlobal` and other methods, which we also use now. These internally unmarshal the version lists. I would have to either duplicate those methods for old migrations to use the old message types or pass the desired message type as an argument to those functions. Or rewrite migrations to not use those kind of methods (that might be possible, as the use of those methods might have been convenience only - likely the case for migration to V1, have to check later ones).

> The double invalid stuff looks fishy.

Actually I might revisit that decision - it doesn't change anything about the migration problem though unfortunately.

I somehow think that having a file with methods to read the old stuff is also fine? I guess at some point we can remove that and add code that says "database too old to migrate". Because at some point you will want to remove the old_versioms, and it's not clear to me when you'll be able to do that.

I started looking into Audrius' approach, as it seems doable with limited amount of old code to keep around. On the flip side that means some modification of old migrations, which obviously is scary, but not that high impact as those are old. Plus converting early to the new format might also have unintended side-effects on old transitions.

On the naming side of things: I will have an old and new variant respectively. In proto the requirements are clear: Old names aren't renamed. Thus I'd go with `V2` suffix (e.g. `FileVersionV2`) for the new variant. On the go side I could use `gogoproto.customname` to name the new variant without any suffix (e.g. `FileVersion`) and the old one with a suffix (e.g. `FileVersionOld1` or `FileVersionDepr1`). I like not having suffixes in the code, however switching around names between proto and go is a source of confusion. Then again I'd say proto stuff is hardly ever looked at. Opinions?
Sorry, whats the issue with renaming stuff to old/deprecated?

Never mind, it's anyway not possible: `gogoproto.customname` is only available on message members, not on the name of messages themselves.

> Sorry, whats the issue with renaming stuff to old/deprecated?

If I change the name of the old/deprecated messages in proto, the unmarshalling of old proto data (dbs on migration, json test data) won't work anymore.
Unmarshalling is done on the field id, not field name. And message names are completely meaningless in proto, as you pass the bytes to some deserializer and that's it.

... argh - yeah of course, thanks for insisting.  
I was wrapping my head around proto the wrong way: I was thinking we tell it to look up `FileVersion` in some data structure... which doesn't exists, we pass the serialized data to a specific type to deserialize. Basic stuff...  
At least that means there wasn't a naming problem in the first place.

I implemented a new global list with version vectors stored once only. The whole diff is a monster - I'll probably put it up for review in step-by-step PRs to a feature branch in the Syncthing repo. The branch lives on top of PR https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/pull/6635, so that's the first thing to happen.  
https://github.com/imsodin/syncthing/tree/indirectversions

One high-level bit for feedback without jumping into the deep end are db migrations:    
They needed a fair bit of code duplication and adjustments to the 0to1 migration. Everything starting with line 751 are old methods: https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/compare/master...imsodin:indirectversions#diff-59e58e2c68f4fbad47386d8ccbaee68cR751  
I haven't looked into Jakobs suggestion above to convert global lists on load and using "the new global list handling" for the old migrations. Given the current amount of duplication, do you think it is worth investing time to give that a try?
